snippet: West Point graduates, faced with the prospect of leading troops who are battle-tested when they themselves are not, are reconsidering their career paths in a military no longer fighting two wars.
abstract: West Point cadets are experiencing career anxiety as end of Iraq war and winding down of war in Afghanistan make it difficult to acquire crucial combat experience; graduates, who could face awkward position of leading troops who have been battle-tested while they themselves have not, are reconsidering their career paths.

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and THOM SHANKER
byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from West Point, and Thom Shanker from Fort Drum, N.Y.

lead_paragraph: West Point graduates, faced with the prospect of leading troops who are battle-tested when they themselves are not, are reconsidering their career paths in a military no longer fighting two wars.

headline.main: In New Officers’ Careers, Peace Is No Dividend
headline.print_headline: In New Officers’ Careers, Peace Is No Dividend

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
